question: Are you serious?
answer: Yeah. No more. I'm finished with that shite.

question: Well, it's up to you.
answer: I'm going to get it right this time. Going to get it set up and get off it for good.

question: Sure, sure. I've heard it before.
Yeah, well, it surely worked for him.
answer: He's always been lacking in moral fibre.

question: He knows a lot about Sean Connery.
Mikey. It's Mark Renton. Can you help me out? I want a fucking hit. For all the good they've done me I might as well have stuck them up my arse. Now. Now I'm ready.
Eh - Ian Fleming?
answer: Fuck off! He never wrote any of them.

question: OK, so who was it, then?
Who wrote it?
answer: But you're looking better, it has to be said. Healthier. Radiant even.

question: You don't know, do you?
answer: And I wondered if you'd care to go to the park tomorrow.

question: It's certainly a phenomenon in all walks of life.
Well, at one time, you've got it, and then you lose it, and it's gone for ever. All walks of life
answer: Some of his solo stuff's not bad.

question: No, it's not bad, but it's not great either, is it? And in your heart you kind of know that although it sounds all right, it's actually just shite.
Charlie Nicholas, David Niven, Malcolm McLaren, Elvis Presley. -
answer: OK, OK, so what's the point you're trying to make?

question: All I'm trying to do is help you understand that The Name of the Rose is merely a blip on an otherwise uninterrupted downward trajectory.
I don't rate that at all.
That means fuck all. The sympathy vote.
answer: Right. So we all get old and then we can't hack it any more. Is that it?

question: Do you see the beast? Have you got it in you sights?
answer: Clear enough, Moneypenny. This should present no significant problem.

question: If they think you're not trying, you're in trouble. First hint of that, they'll be on to the DSS, 'This cunt's no trying' and your Giro is fucking finished, right?
But try too hard --
answer: And you might get the fucking job.

question: It's a tightrope, Spud, a fucking tightrope.
answer: My problem is that I tend to clam up. I go dumb and I can't answer any questions at all. Nerves on the big occasion, like a footballer.

question: Try this.
answer: A little dab of speed is just the ticket.

question: Well, Mr. Renton, I see that you attended the Royal Edinburgh College.
One of Edinburgh's finest schools.
answer: Oh, yes, indeed. I look back on my time there with great fondness and affection. The debating society, the first eleven, the soft know of willow on leather --

question: I'm an old boy myself, you know?
Do you recall the school motto?
answer: Of course, the motto, the motto --

question: Strive, hope, believe and conquer.
answer: Exactly. Those very words have been my guiding light in what is, after all, a dark and often hostile world. Yes. Yes, I can. The truth -- well, the truth is that I've had a long-standing problem with heroin addiction. I've been know to sniff it, smoke it, swallow it, stick it up my arse and inject it into my veins. I've been trying to combat this addiction, but unless you count social security scams and shoplifting, I haven't had a regular job in years. I feel it's important to mention this.

question: No, actually I went to Craignewton but I was worried that you wouldn't have heard of it so I put the Royal Edinburgh College instead, because they're both schools, right, and we're all in this together, and I wanted to put across the general idea rather than the details, yeah? People get all hung up on details, but what's the point? Like which school? Does it matter? Why? When? Where? Or how many O grades did I get? Could be six, could be one, but that's not important. What's important is that I am, right? That I am.
answer: Mr. Murphy, do you mean that you lied on your application?

question: Only to get my foot in the door. Showing initiative, right?
answer: You were referred here by the Department of Employment. There's no need for you to get you "foot in the door", as you put it.

question: Hey. Right. No problem. Whatever you say, man. You're the man, the governor, the dude in the chair, like. I'm merely here. But obviously I am. Here, that is. I hope I'm not talking too much. I don't usually. I think it's all important though, isn't it? In a word, pleasure. My pleasure in other people's leisure.
answer: What do you see as your main strengths?

question: I love people. All people. Even people that no one else loves, I think they're OK, you know. Like Beggars.

No, not homeless people. Beggars, Francis Begbie -- one of my mates. I wouldn't say my best mate, I mean, sometimes the boy goes over the score, like one time when we -- me and him -- were having a laugh and all of a sudden he's fucking gubbed me in the face, right --
answer: Mr. Murphy, {leaving your friend aside,} do you see yourself as having any weaknesses?

question: Six weeks!
answer: It's a nightmare. She told me she didn't want our relationship to start on a physical basis as that is how it would be principally defined from then on in.

question: Where did she come up with that?
Six weeks and no sex?
answer: I've got balls like watermelons, I'm telling you.

question: Actually it's a nightmare. I've been desperate for a shag, but watching him suffer was just too much fun. You should try it with Tommy.
answer: What, and deny myself the only pleasure I get from him? Did I tell you about my birthday?

question: Useless motherfucker, that's what she called me. I told her, I'm sorry, but theses things happen. Let's put it behind us.
Yes, but then she finds out I've bought a ticket for Iggy Pop the same night.
Big time. Absolutely fucking radge. 'It's me or Iggy Pop, time to decide.'
answer: So what's it going to be?

question: Excuse me, I don't mean to harass you, but I was very impressed by the capable and stylish manner in which you dealt with that situation. I thought to myself
I'll come back if you like, but I'm not promising anything.
answer: Do you find that this approach usually works, or, let me guess, you've never tried it before. In fact, you don't normally approach girls, am I right? The truth is that you're a quite, sensitive type but if I'm prepared to take a chance I might just get to know the inner you

question: Eh-
answer: Well, what's wrong, boy? Cat got your tongue.

question: Christ, I haven't felt that good since Archie Gemmill scored against Holland in 1978.
Come on.
answer: No argument. You can sleep on the sofa in the living room, or go home. It's up to you.

question: I'll put the sheets in the washing machine just now.
answer: No, I'll wash them. I'll take them home and bring them back.

question: No problem for me either. Honestly, it's no problem.
answer: I'd really rather take care of it myself.

question: Spud, they're my sheets.
answer: I guess this means I'll never get to have sex with Gail.

question: In that case you can do it. You were quite happy to do a lot more last night.
answer: And that's what's illegal. Do you know what they do to people like me inside? They'd cut my balls off and flush them down the fucking toilet.

question: Calm down. You're not going to jail.
This had better be good.
answer: It will be. It'll make a change for three miserable junkies who don't know what they want to do with themselves since they stopped doing smack.

question: If I'm giving up a whole day and the price of a ticket, I'm just saying it had better be good. There's plenty of other things I could be doing.
Such as sitting in a darkened room, watching videos, drinking, smoking dope and wanking. Does that answer your question? Now what?
It's the great outdoors.
answer: It's really nice, Tommy. Can we go home now?

question: It's fresh air.
answer: Look, Tommy, we know you're getting a hard time off Lizzy, but there's no need to take it out on us.

question: What's on the menu this evening?
Why, thank you.
answer: And would sir care to settle his bill in advance?

question: Stick it on my tab.
answer: Regret to inform, sir, that your credit limit was reached and breached a long time ago.

question: In that case --
answer: Oh, hard currency, why, sir, that'll do nicely.

question: No, thank you. I'll proceed directly to the intravenous injection of hard drugs, please.
answer: As you wish. Perhaps sir would like me to call for a taxi?

question: We'll help you, son. You'll stay with us until you get better. We'll beat this together.
answer: Maybe I could go back to the clinic.

question: No. No clinics, no methadone. That made you worse, you said so yourself. You lied to us, son, your own mother and father.
answer: At least get us some Tempazepam.

question: I'm sorry, Tommy.
answer: Have you got any gear on you?

question: No, I'm clean.
answer: Well, sub us, then, mate. I'm expecting a rent cheque.

question: Great.
answer: And see when I get out of here. I've got plans. Going to get myself straightened out and head off to Thailand, where women really know how to treat a guy. See, out there you can live like a king if you've got white skin and a few crisp tenners in your pocket. No fucking problem.

question: You'll have to send us a postcard.
You know.
answer: No, he didn't make me touch it.

question: Oh no, don't even mention it.
God, you're sick.
answer: And I got a stitch stuck between my teeth, jerked my head back and the whole fucking stump fell off.

question: Cut it out.
answer: When are you going to visit him?

question: Don't know. Maybe Thursday.
answer: You're a real mate. And what about Tommy? Have you been to see him yet?

question: Fuck you. OK, so Tommy's got the virus. Bad news, big deal. The gig goes on, or hadn't you noticed? Swanney fucks his leg up. Well, tough shit, but it could have been worse.

I know a couple of addicts. Stupid wee lassies. I feed them what they need. A little bit of skag to keep them happy while the punters line up at a fiver a skull. It's easy money for me. Not exactly a fortune, but I'm thinking, 'I should be coining it here.' Less whores, more skag. Swanney's right. Get clean, get into dealing, that's where the future lies. Set up some contacts, get a good load of skag, punt it, profit. What do you think?
And I'll tell you why. Because I'm fed up to my back teeth with losers, no-hopers, draftpacks, schemies, junkies and the like. I'm getting on with life. What are you doing?
Yes, as a matter of fact, it is.
answer: Calm down, I'm just asking. Is that hash I can smell?

question: No.
answer: I wouldn't mind a bit, if it is.

question: You're too young.
answer: Too young for what? You're not getting any younger, Mark. The world is changing, music is changing, even drugs are changing. You can't stay in here all day dreaming about heroin and Ziggy Pop.

question: It's Iggy Pop.
answer: Whatever. I mean, the guy's dead anyway.

question: Iggy Pop is not dead. He toured last year. Tommy went to see him.
answer: The point is, you've got to find something new.

question: Armed robbery? With a replica? How can it be armed robbery? It's a fucking scandal.
Too right it is. Now look, have you got anything to eat, 'cos I'm fucking Lee Marvin, by the way.
Good chips.
answer: I can't believe you did that.

question: I got a good price for it. Rents, I need the money.
Well, Christ, if I'd known you were going to get so humpty about it, I wouldn't have bothered. Are you going to eat that?
Well, this guy I've met runs a hotel. Brother. Loads of contacts. Does a nice little sideline in punting British passports to foreigners. Get you a good price.
answer: Why would I want to sell my passport?

question: He wanted to see Lizzy again.
answer: I bet Lizzy told him where to put it.

question: Exactly. I'm not wanting a cat, she says. Get to fuck, right. So there's Tommy stuck with this kitten. You can imagine what happened. The thing was neglected, pissing and shitting all over the place. Tommy was lying around fucked out of his eyeballs on smack or downers. He didn't know you could get toxoplasmosis from cat shit.
answer: I didn't either. What the fuck is it?

question: What?
answer: There's a mate of swanney's. Mikey Forrester -- you know the guy. He's come into some gear. A lot of gear.

question: How much?
answer: About four kilos. So he tells me. Got drunk in a pub down by the docks last week, where he met two Russian sailors. They're fucking carrying the stuff. For sale there and then, like. So he wakes up the next morning, realizes what he's done and get very fucking nervous. Wants rid of this. {---------- He's looking for Swanney to punt it, but Swanney's nowhere to be seen since he lost his leg. ----------}

question: So?
answer: So he met me and I offered to take it off his hands at a very reasonable price, with the intention of punting it on myself to a guy I know in London.

question: But you don't have the money?
That's tough.
answer: Come on, Mark, every cunt knows you've been saving up down in London.

question: Sorry, boys, I don't have two thousand pounds.
answer: Yes, you fucking do. I've seen your statement.

question: Jesus.
answer: Two thousand, one hundred and thirty-three pounds.

question: It's so simple. We buy it at four grand, we punt it at twenty to this guy that Sick Boy knows, and he punts it at sixty. Everyone's happy, everyone's in profit. I put up two. I come away with six.
So long as everyone keeps their mouths shut, we'll not be getting caught.
answer: So why have you told me about it?

question: Well, you're not going to tell anyone, are you, and besides, I thought we could meet up afterwards, maybe go somewhere together.
And what age are you? Thirteen? Fourteen?
Happy birthday.
answer: What do you think -- I should be carrying a torch for you?

question: So, what's he like?
answer: Well, he's young and he's healthy.

question: The cards. The last thing I said to you was mind the cards.
It's fucking boring after a while without the cards.
It's fucking boring after a while without the cards.
Bit fucking late, like.
answer: Well, why didn't you bring them?

question: Because I fucking told you to do that, you doss cunt.
We didn't get followed.
answer: So what do you want for it?

question: Twenty thousand.
answer: But it's not worth more than fifteen.

question: Ninteen.
answer: Nineteen I can't offer you, I'm sorry.

question: For four fucking grand? One plam tree, a couple of rocks, and a sewage outflow.
answer: I don't know, maybe I'll buy something for my ma, and then buy some good speed, no bicarb like, then get a girl, take her out like, and treat her -- properly.

question: Shag her senseless.
answer: No, I don't mean like that -- I mean something nice, like, that's all --

question: For fuck's sake.
answer: Sorry, mate, I'll get you another.

question: All down my fucking front, you fucking idiot.
answer: Look, I'm sorry, I didn't mean it.
